data.title: introduction to the listing of japanese prisoners of war and internees ...
data.meta_description: introduction to the listing of japanese prisoners of war and internees ...
data.text: INTRODUCTION TO THE LISTING OF JAPANESE PRISONERS OF WAR AND INTERNEES HELD IN AUSTRALIA FROM 1941 TO 1947 When Japan attacked Pearl Harbour, Australia was also at war with Japan. Japanese civilians in Australia were rounded up and interned, but it went further than that. Japanese people or family members of Japanese were also interned as were such people from many other places outside Australia such as Indonesia and New Caledonia. People of mixed race who were married to a Japanese or children from such relationships were also interned. One lady who was listed as ¾ Aboriginal was interned because she was part Japanese. Many Japanese had been in Australia for two generations but were still interned. To read more about this subject see Yuriko Nagata’s excellent book “Unwanted Aliens – Japanese Internment in Australia” (University of Queensland Press). Japanese military personnel were also interned as they were captured or surrendered in the various campaigns in New Guinea and the Pacific. Military personnel were interned in either Cowra or Hay, whereas civilians tended to be interned in Gaythorne, Tatura or Loveday camps. Many children were interned and a number were also born in the camps after 1941 through to 1946. Due to the lack of shipping after WWII, some POW were not sent home until 1946 or 1947. Many Japanese, even those not born in Japan, were repatriated. The lists are presented with Japanese last name by the given names in the first column and year of birth in the second column. Sometimes you will see more than one name in each box such as Kumagai aka Kumaya, Takanobu aka Takanopu. “aka” means “also known as” and the individual has used an alias for both their surname and given name. The listing is extensive and cointains over 5,000 names arranged in year of birth from 1849 to 1946 and then alphabetically. Civillians and Military are listed togther. Military personnel will be found in the military service age groups from year of birth 1900 to 1925 approximately. If you know a particular name you can use the normal search facility in Microsoft Word to locate. If you want to read more about a particular person you should 1. block the full name, 2. copy it 3. click the link to the National Archives http://www.naa.gov.au/the_collection/recordsearch.html 4. click on RECORDS SEARCH 5. then paste the name into the box marked Keywords (or name) You will then get an image of that person’s original record card and find out where they were captured wherer they came from in Japan, occupation etc. See example below.
